natural problem:
A triangular array of squares has one square in the first row, two in the second, and in general, $k$ squares in the $k$th row for $1 \leq k \leq 11.$ With the exception of the bottom row, each square rests on two squares in the row immediately below (illustrated in the given diagram). In each square of the eleventh row, a $0$ or a $1$ is placed. Numbers are then placed into the other squares, with the entry for each square being the sum of the entries in the two squares below it. For how many initial distributions of $0$'s and $1$'s in the bottom row is the number in the top square a multiple of $3$?
[asy] for (int i=0; i<12; ++i){  for (int j=0; j<i; ++j){    //dot((-j+i/2,-i));    draw((-j+i/2,-i)--(-j+i/2+1,-i)--(-j+i/2+1,-i+1)--(-j+i/2,-i+1)--cycle);  } } [/asy]
natural solution: Label each of the bottom squares as $x_0, x_1 \ldots x_9, x_{10}$. Through induction, we can find that the top square is equal to ${10\choose0}x_0 + {10\choose1}x_1 + {10\choose2}x_2 + \ldots {10\choose10}x_{10}$.

(This also makes sense based on a combinatorial argument: the number of ways a number can "travel" to the top position going only up is equal to the number of times it will be counted in the final sum.)
Examine the equation $\mod 3$. All of the coefficients from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ will be multiples of $3$ (since the numerator will have a $9$).

Thus, the expression boils down to $x_0 + 10x_1 + 10x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Reduce to find that $x_0 + x_1 + x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Out of $x_0,\ x_1,\ x_9,\ x_{10}$, either all are equal to $0$, or three of them are equal to $1$.

This gives ${4\choose0} + {4\choose3} = 1 + 4 = 5$ possible combinations of numbers that work. The seven terms from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ can assume either $0$ or $1$, giving us $2^7$ possibilities. The answer is therefore $5 \cdot 2^7 = \boxed{640}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle :: "(int \<times> int) \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> n. (\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> k \<longrightarrow> triangle (k, i) = n))"
and h1 : "\<forall>k i. 1 \<le> k \<and> k < 11 \<and> 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> k \<longrightarrow> triangle (k, i) = triangle (k + 1, i) + triangle (k + 1, i + 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (triangle (11, i) = 0 \<or> triangle (11, i) = 1)"
and h3 : "\<exists>count. (\<forall>dist. (\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> dist i = 0 \<or> dist i = 1) \<longrightarrow> (triangle (1, 1) mod 3 = 0) = (count = count + 1))"
shows  "count = 640"

 The final Answer is 640

 (This also makes sense based on a combinatorial argument: the number of ways a number can "travel" to the top position going only up is equal to the number of times it will be counted in the final sum.)

theorem
fixes triangle :: "(int \<times> int) \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> n. (\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> k \<longrightarrow> triangle (k, i) = n))"
and h1 : "\<forall>k i. 1 \<le> k \<and> k < 11 \<and> 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> k \<longrightarrow> triangle (k, i) = triangle (k + 1, i) + triangle (k + 1, i + 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (triangle (11, i) = 0 \<or> triangle (11, i) = 1)"
and h3 : "\<exists>count. (\<forall>dist. (\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> dist i = 0 \<or> dist i = 1) \<longrightarrow> (triangle (1, 1) mod 3 = 0) = (count = count + 1))"
shows  "count = 640"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
In a triangular grid with 11 rows, each cell (k, i) contains an integer value, where 1 ≤ k ≤ 11 and 1 ≤ i ≤ k. The value in each cell (k, i) is equal to the sum of the values in cells (k+1, i) and (k+1, i+1) for k < 11. The last row (k = 11) contains only 0s and 1s.

Now, consider a distribution where each cell value is either 0 or 1, and the value in the top cell (1, 1) is divisible by 3. How many such distributions exist? The final answer is 640.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangular_array :: "(nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
and eleventh_row :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>i < k. \<exists>x y. triangular_array (x, y) = triangular_array (x, y + 1) + triangular_array (x + 1, y + 1))"
and h1 : "\<forall>i < 11. eleventh_row i = (0::nat) \<or> eleventh_row i = (1::nat)"
and h2 : "triangular_array (1, 1) mod 3 = 0"
shows  "\<exists>initial_distribution. count initial_distribution eleventh_row = 640"

(* ### Problem
 A triangular array of squares has one square in the first row, two in the second, and in general, $k$ squares in the $k$th row for $1 \leq k \leq 11.$ With the exception of the bottom row, each square rests on two squares in the row immediately below (illustrated in the given diagram). For how many initial distributions of $0$'s and $1$'s in the bottom row is the number in the top square a multiple of $3$?

 The final Answer is 640
 ### Proof
 Label each of the bottom squares as $x_0, x_1 \ldots x_9, x_{10}$. Through induction, we can find that the top square is equal to ${10\choose0}x_0 + {10\choose1}x_1 + {10\choose2}x_2 + \ldots {10\choose10}x_{10}$.
 (This also makes sense based on a combinatorial argument: the number of ways a number can "travel" to the top position going only up is equal to the number of times it will be counted in the final sum.)
 Examine the equation $\mod 3$. All of the coefficients from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ will be multiples of $3$ (since the numerator will have a $9$).
 Thus, the expression boils down to $x_0 + 10x_1 + 10x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Reduce to find that $x_0 + x_1 + x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Out of $x_0,\ x_1,\ x_9,\ x_{10}$, either all are equal to $0$, or three of them are equal to $1$.
 This gives ${4\choose0} + {4\choose3} = 1 + 4 = 5$ possible combinations of numbers that work. The seven terms from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ can assume either $0$ or $1$, giving us $2^7$ possibilities. The answer is therefore $5 \cdot 2^7 = \boxed{640}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangular_array :: "(nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
and eleventh_row :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>i < k. \<exists>x y. triangular_array (x, y) = triangular_array (x, y + 1) + triangular_array (x + 1, y + 1))"
and h1 : "\<forall>i < 11. eleventh_row i = (0::nat) \<or> eleventh_row i = (1::nat)"
and h2 : "triangular_array (1, 1) mod 3 = 0"
shows  "\<exists>initial_distribution. count initial_distribution eleventh_row = 640"

a_1.informal problem: In a triangular array, every number is the sum of the two numbers immediately below it. Each entry in the array is a non-negative integer. In the eleventh row of the array, all the numbers are either 0 or 1. If the first entry in the array is divisible by 3, how many ways are there to distribute the numbers in the eleventh row such that the given conditions are met? The final answer is 640.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "(int \<times> int) \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> k \<longrightarrow> (k, j) \<in> Domain f)"
and h1 : "\<forall>k j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> k \<and> 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> f (k, j) = (if k = 11 then f (k, j) mod 2 else f (k-1, j-1) + f (k-1, j))"
and h2 : "\<forall>k j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> k \<and> 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> f (k, j) \<in> Domain f"
and h3 : "let n = count (range f) (\<lambda>x. x mod 3 = 0) in n = 640"
shows  "f (1, 1) mod 3 = 0"

(* ### Problem

theorem
fixes f :: "(int \<times> int) \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> k \<longrightarrow> (k, j) \<in> Domain f)"
and h1 : "\<forall>k j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> k \<and> 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> f (k, j) = (if k = 11 then f (k, j) mod 2 else f (k-1, j-1) + f (k-1, j))"
and h2 : "\<forall>k j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> k \<and> 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 10 \<longrightarrow> f (k, j) \<in> Domain f"
and h3 : "let n = count (range f) (\<lambda>x. x mod 3 = 0) in n = 640"
shows  "f (1, 1) mod 3 = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
A function $f$ is defined on a domain of integer pairs $(k, j)$ such that $1 \leq j \leq k \leq 11$. The function is defined recursively as follows:

1. For $1 \leq k \leq 11$ and $1 \leq j \leq k$, $(k, j) \in Domain\ f$.
2. For $1 \leq j \leq k \leq 11$, $f(k, j) = \begin{cases}
  f(k-1, j-1) + f(k-1, j) & \text{if}\ k \neq 11 \\
  f(k, j) \bmod 2 & \text{if}\ k = 11
\end{cases}$
3. For $1 \leq j \leq k \leq 10$, $f(k, j) \in Domain\ f$.
4. The count of numbers in the range of $f$ that are divisible by 3 is 640.

Find the value of $f(1, 1) \bmod 3$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes k :: nat and triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>i < k. triangle k i \<in> {0, 1})"
and h1 : "\<forall>k i. 1 < k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<and> i < k - 1 \<longrightarrow> triangle (k - 1) i = triangle k i + triangle k (i + 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>k i. 1 < k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<and> i < k - 1 \<and> triangle (k - 1) i mod 3 = 0"
shows  "\<exists> n. n = 640 \<and> (\<forall> k i. 1 < k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<and> i < k - 1 \<longrightarrow> triangle (k - 1) i mod 3 = 0)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular array of squares has one square in the first row, two in the second, and in general, $k$ squares in the $k$th row for $1 \leq k \leq 11.$ With the exception of the bottom row, each square rests on two squares in the row immediately below (illustrated in the given diagram). In each square of the eleventh row, a $0$ or a $1$ is placed. Numbers are then placed into the other squares, with the entry for each square being the sum of the entries in the two squares below it. For how many initial distributions of $0$'s and $1$'s in the bottom row is the number in the top square a multiple of $3$?
[asy] for (int i=0; i<12; ++i){  for (int j=0; j<i; ++j){    //dot((-j+i/2,-i));    draw((-j+i/2,-i)--(-j+i/2+1,-i)--(-j+i/2+1,-i+1)--(-j+i/2,-i+1)--cycle);  } } [/asy]
 The final Answer is 640
 ### Proof
 Label each of the bottom squares as $x_0, x_1 \ldots x_9, x_{10}$. Through induction, we can find that the top square is equal to ${10\choose0}x_0 + {10\choose1}x_1 + {10\choose2}x_2 + \ldots {10\choose10}x_{10}$.
 (This also makes sense based on a combinatorial argument: the number of ways a number can "travel" to the top position going only up is equal to the number of times it will be counted in the final sum.)
 Examine the equation $\mod 3$. All of the coefficients from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ will be multiples of $3$ (since the numerator will have a $9$).
 Thus, the expression boils down to $x_0 + 10x_1 + 10x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Reduce to find that $x_0 + x_1 + x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Out of $x_0,\ x_1,\ x_9,\ x_{10}$, either all are equal to $0$, or three of them are equal to $1$.
 This gives ${4\choose0} + {4\choose3} = 1 + 4 = 5$ possible combinations of numbers that work. The seven terms from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ can assume either $0$ or $1$, giving us $2^7$ possibilities. The answer is therefore $5 \cdot 2^7 = \boxed{640}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes k :: nat and triangle :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>i < k. triangle k i \<in> {0, 1})"
and h1 : "\<forall>k i. 1 < k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<and> i < k - 1 \<longrightarrow> triangle (k - 1) i = triangle k i + triangle k (i + 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>k i. 1 < k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<and> i < k - 1 \<and> triangle (k - 1) i mod 3 = 0"
shows  "\<exists> n. n = 640 \<and> (\<forall> k i. 1 < k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<and> i < k - 1 \<longrightarrow> triangle (k - 1) i mod 3 = 0)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
Consider a triangular array of numbers with 11 rows, where each row has one more entry than the one above it. The entries in the first row are all 1's, and each entry in the subsequent rows is obtained by summing the two entries above it.

Let's denote the entries of this triangle by $T(k, i)$, where $k$ is the row number (starting from 1) and $i$ is the index of the entry in that row (starting from 0). In this triangle, the following properties hold:

1. For all rows $k$ from 1 to 11, every entry in the row is either 0 or 1.
2. For all rows $k$ from 2 to 11 and each entry $i$ in that row (excluding the last entry), the entry in the row above ($T(k - 1, i)$) is equal to the sum of the current entry and the next entry in the same row ($T(k, i) + T(k, i + 1)$).
3. For all rows $k$ from 2 to 11 and each entry $i$ in that row (excluding the last entry), the entry in the row above ($T(k - 1, i)$) is divisible by 3.

Find a number $n$ such that $n = 640$ and the above properties hold for the triangular array of numbers.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem count_triple_multiples:
  fixes n :: nat and initial_distribution :: "nat list"
  assumes h0 : "n = 11"
and h1 : "length initial_distribution = n"
and h2 : "set initial_distribution \<subseteq> {0, 1}"
and h3 : "\<forall> i < length initial_distribution - 1.
                         nth initial_distribution i + nth initial_distribution (i + 1)
                         = nth (initial_distribution[1 := nth initial_distribution 1 + nth initial_distribution 0]) (i + 1)"
shows  "card {i. i < 2 ^ n \<and> (sum_list (generate_distribution i)) mod 3 = 0} = 640"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular array of squares has one square in the first row, two in the second, and in general, $k$ squares in the $k$th row for $1 \leq k \leq 11.$ With the exception of the bottom row, each square rests on two squares in the row immediately below (illustrated in the given diagram). In each square of the eleventh row, a $0$ or a $1$ is placed. Numbers are then placed into the other squares, with the entry for each square being the sum of the entries in the two squares below it. For how many initial distributions of $0$'s and $1$'s in the bottom row is the number in the top square a multiple of $3$?
[asy] for (int i=0; i<12; ++i){  for (int j=0; j<i; ++j){    //dot((-j+i/2,-i));    draw((-j+i/2,-i)--(-j+i/2+1,-i)--(-j+i/2+1,-i+1)--(-j+i/2,-i+1)--cycle);  } } [/asy]
 The final Answer is 640
 ### Proof
 Label each of the bottom squares as $x_0, x_1 \ldots x_9, x_{10}$. Through induction, we can find that the top square is equal to ${10\choose0}x_0 + {10\choose1}x_1 + {10\choose2}x_2 + \ldots {10\choose10}x_{10}$.
 (This also makes sense based on a combinatorial argument: the number of ways a number can "travel" to the top position going only up is equal to the number of times it will be counted in the final sum.)
 Examine the equation $\mod 3$. All of the coefficients from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ will be multiples of $3$ (since the numerator will have a $9$).
 Thus, the expression boils down to $x_0 + 10x_1 + 10x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Reduce to find that $x_0 + x_1 + x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Out of $x_0,\ x_1,\ x_9,\ x_{10}$, either all are equal to $0$, or three of them are equal to $1$.
 This gives ${4\choose0} + {4\choose3} = 1 + 4 = 5$ possible combinations of numbers that work. The seven terms from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ can assume either $0$ or $1$, giving us $2^7$ possibilities. The answer is therefore $5 \cdot 2^7 = \boxed{640}$.
 *)

theorem count_triple_multiples:
  fixes n :: nat and initial_distribution :: "nat list"
  assumes h0 : "n = 11"
and h1 : "length initial_distribution = n"
and h2 : "set initial_distribution \<subseteq> {0, 1}"
and h3 : "\<forall> i < length initial_distribution - 1.
                         nth initial_distribution i + nth initial_distribution (i + 1)
                         = nth (initial_distribution[1 := nth initial_distribution 1 + nth initial_distribution 0]) (i + 1)"
shows  "card {i. i < 2 ^ n \<and> (sum_list (generate_distribution i)) mod 3 = 0} = 640"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider a sequence of 11 elements, where each element is either 0 or 1. After the first element, each element is the sum of itself and the previous element in the sequence. How many distinct sequences are there such that the sum of all elements in the sequence is divisible by 3? The final answer is 640.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangular_array :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> length (triangular_array k) = k"
and h1 : "\<forall>k i. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 10 \<and> i < k \<longrightarrow> triangular_array k ! i = triangular_array (k + 1) ! i + triangular_array (k + 1) ! (i + 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. i < 11 \<longrightarrow> triangular_array 11 ! i \<in> {0, 1}"
and h3 : "count (\<lambda>bottom_row. triangular_array 1 ! 0 mod 3 = 0) (all_bottom_row_permutations 11) = 640"
shows  "\<exists>! f. f 1 = 640"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 *)

theorem
fixes triangular_array :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat list"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> length (triangular_array k) = k"
and h1 : "\<forall>k i. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 10 \<and> i < k \<longrightarrow> triangular_array k ! i = triangular_array (k + 1) ! i + triangular_array (k + 1) ! (i + 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. i < 11 \<longrightarrow> triangular_array 11 ! i \<in> {0, 1}"
and h3 : "count (\<lambda>bottom_row. triangular_array 1 ! 0 mod 3 = 0) (all_bottom_row_permutations 11) = 640"
shows  "\<exists>! f. f 1 = 640"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem:
Consider a triangular array with 11 rows, where each row has a length equal to its row number (i.e., the first row has 1 element, the second row has 2 elements, and so on). The elements of the array are non-negative integers such that for each row from the first to the tenth, the sum of every two adjacent elements in that row is equal to the element directly below them in the next row. Additionally, every element in the 11th row is either 0 or 1. 

Find the unique number of ways to arrange the elements in the bottom row of the array such that the element in the first row is divisible by 3. The final answer is 640.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangular_array :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>n \<in> {0..<k}. triangular_array k n \<in> {0, 1})"
and h1 : "\<forall>k n. 1 \<le> k \<and> k < 11 \<and> n < k \<longrightarrow> triangular_array (k - 1) n = triangular_array k n + triangular_array k (n + 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>n \<in> {0..<11}. triangular_array 11 n \<in> {0, 1}"
and h3 : "\<forall>f. (\<forall>n \<in> {0..<11}. f n = triangular_array 11 n) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>count. (\<forall>n \<in> {0..<11}. f n = triangular_array 11 n) \<and> triangular_array 0 0 mod 3 = 0 \<and> count = 640))"
shows  "\<exists>count. count = 640"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular array of squares has one square in the first row, two in the second, and in general, $k$ squares in the $k$th row for $1 \leq k \leq 11.$ With the exception of the bottom row, each square rests on two squares in the row immediately below (illustrated in the given diagram). In each square of the eleventh row, a $0$ or a $1$ is placed. Numbers are then placed into the other squares, with the entry for each square being the sum of the entries in the two squares below it. For how many initial distributions of $0$'s and $1$'s in the bottom row is the number in the top square a multiple of $3$?
[asy] for (int i=0; i<12; ++i){  for (int j=0; j<i; ++j){    //dot((-j+i/2,-i));    draw((-j+i/2,-i)--(-j+i/2+1,-i)--(-j+i/2+1,-i+1)--(-j+i/2,-i+1)--cycle);  } } [/asy]
 The final Answer is 640
 ### Proof
 Label each of the bottom squares as $x_0, x_1 \ldots x_9, x_{10}$. Through induction, we can find that the top square is equal to ${10\choose0}x_0 + {10\choose1}x_1 + {10\choose2}x_2 + \ldots {10\choose10}x_{10}$.
 (This also makes sense based on a combinatorial argument: the number of ways a number can "travel" to the top position going only up is equal to the number of times it will be counted in the final sum.)
 Examine the equation $\mod 3$. All of the coefficients from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ will be multiples of $3$ (since the numerator will have a $9$).
 Thus, the expression boils down to $x_0 + 10x_1 + 10x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Reduce to find that $x_0 + x_1 + x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Out of $x_0,\ x_1,\ x_9,\ x_{10}$, either all are equal to $0$, or three of them are equal to $1$.
 This gives ${4\choose0} + {4\choose3} = 1 + 4 = 5$ possible combinations of numbers that work. The seven terms from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ can assume either $0$ or $1$, giving us $2^7$ possibilities. The answer is therefore $5 \cdot 2^7 = \boxed{640}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangular_array :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>n \<in> {0..<k}. triangular_array k n \<in> {0, 1})"
and h1 : "\<forall>k n. 1 \<le> k \<and> k < 11 \<and> n < k \<longrightarrow> triangular_array (k - 1) n = triangular_array k n + triangular_array k (n + 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>n \<in> {0..<11}. triangular_array 11 n \<in> {0, 1}"
and h3 : "\<forall>f. (\<forall>n \<in> {0..<11}. f n = triangular_array 11 n) \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>count. (\<forall>n \<in> {0..<11}. f n = triangular_array 11 n) \<and> triangular_array 0 0 mod 3 = 0 \<and> count = 640))"
shows  "\<exists>count. count = 640"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: There is a triangular array of numbers with 11 rows, where each number in the array is either 0 or 1. The numbers in the first 10 rows follow the rule that the number in row k-1 and position n is equal to the sum of the numbers in row k at positions n and n+1 for 1 ≤ k < 11. In the last row, the numbers are either 0 or 1. There is a function f that maps the numbers in the last row to the array. Find the number of such triangular arrays where the first element in the array, triangular_array 0 0, is divisible by 3. The final answer is 640.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangular_array :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. triangular_array (\<lambda> i j. if i = 11 then (if j \<le> i then (if j mod 2 = 0 then 1 else 0) else 0) else triangular_array (\<lambda> i j. triangular_array (\<lambda> i (j-1)) + triangular_array (\<lambda> i (j-2))))"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. triangular_array (\<lambda> i j. if i = 0 then (if j mod 3 = 0 then 1 else 0) else triangular_array (\<lambda> i (j-1)))"
shows  "triangular_array (\<lambda> i j. if j = 0 then (if i mod 3 = 0 then 1 else 0) else triangular_array (\<lambda> i (j-1))) = 640"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular array of squares has one square in the first row, two in the second, and in general, $k$ squares in the $k$th row for $1 \leq k \leq 11.$ With the exception of the bottom row, each square rests on two squares in the row immediately below (illustrated in the given diagram).  This gives ${4\choose0} + {4\choose3} = 1 + 4 = 5$ possible combinations of numbers that work. The seven terms from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ can assume either $0$ or $1$, giving us $2^7$ possibilities. The answer is therefore $5 \cdot 2^7 = \boxed{640}$.

theorem
fixes triangular_array :: "(nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. triangular_array (\<lambda> i j. if i = 11 then (if j \<le> i then (if j mod 2 = 0 then 1 else 0) else 0) else triangular_array (\<lambda> i j. triangular_array (\<lambda> i (j-1)) + triangular_array (\<lambda> i (j-2))))"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. triangular_array (\<lambda> i j. if i = 0 then (if j mod 3 = 0 then 1 else 0) else triangular_array (\<lambda> i (j-1)))"
shows  "triangular_array (\<lambda> i j. if j = 0 then (if i mod 3 = 0 then 1 else 0) else triangular_array (\<lambda> i (j-1))) = 640"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
Define a triangular array as follows:

1. For row $i = 11$, the array has 1's in even positions and 0's in odd positions, for all positions $j \le i$.
2. For row $i = 0$, the array has 1's in positions that are multiples of 3 and 0's otherwise.
3. For all other rows, the value in position $j$ is the sum of the values in positions $(j-1)$ and $(j-2)$ of the previous row.

Find the value in position $(i, j)$ when $j = 0$ and $i$ is a multiple of 3. The final answer is 640.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_distributions :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> initial_distributions. (\<forall> square \<in> initial_distributions. square = 0 \<or> square = 1) \<and> (\<forall> square \<in> initial_distributions. (\<exists> sum_top_square. sum_top_square = (\<Sum> squares_below \<in> {square_below. square_below \<in> initial_distributions \<and> (square, square_below) \<in> resting_on}. squares_below) \<and> sum_top_square mod 3 = 0))"
shows  "num_distributions = 640"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular array of squares has one square in the first row, two in the second, and in general, $k$ squares in the $k$th row for $1 \leq k \leq 11.$ With the exception of the bottom row, each square rests on two squares in the row immediately below (illustrated in the given diagram).  (This also makes sense based on a combinatorial argument: the number of ways a number can "travel" to the top position going only up is equal to the number of times it will be counted in the final sum.)

theorem
fixes num_distributions :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> initial_distributions. (\<forall> square \<in> initial_distributions. square = 0 \<or> square = 1) \<and> (\<forall> square \<in> initial_distributions. (\<exists> sum_top_square. sum_top_square = (\<Sum> squares_below \<in> {square_below. square_below \<in> initial_distributions \<and> (square, square_below) \<in> resting_on}. squares_below) \<and> sum_top_square mod 3 = 0))"
shows  "num_distributions = 640"

a_8.informal problem: There are 11 squares that can be stacked, and each square can have an initial distribution of either 0 or 1. Find the number of possible distributions where for every square, the sum of the squares below it that it is resting on is divisible by 3. The final answer is 640.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes k :: nat and triangular_array :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> k \<longrightarrow> triangular_array k i = (triangular_array (k - 1) (i - 1) + triangular_array (k - 1) i) mod 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> triangular_array 11 i \<in> {0, 1}"
and h2 : "count (\<lambda> x. triangular_array 1 1 = x mod 3) [0, 1] = 640"
shows  "count (\<lambda> x. triangular_array 1 1 = x mod 3) [0, 1] = 640"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangular array of squares has one square in the first row, two in the second, and in general, $k$ squares in the $k$th row for $1 \leq k \leq 11.$ With the exception of the bottom row, each square rests on two squares in the row immediately below (illustrated in the given diagram). In each square of the eleventh row, a $0$ or a $1$ is placed. Numbers are then placed into the other squares, with the entry for each square being the sum of the entries in the two squares below it. For how many initial distributions of $0$'s and $1$'s in the bottom row is the number in the top square a multiple of $3$?
[asy] for (int i=0; i<12; ++i){  for (int j=0; j<i; ++j){    //dot((-j+i/2,-i));    draw((-j+i/2,-i)--(-j+i/2+1,-i)--(-j+i/2+1,-i+1)--(-j+i/2,-i+1)--cycle);  } } [/asy]
 The final Answer is 640
 ### Proof
 Label each of the bottom squares as $x_0, x_1 \ldots x_9, x_{10}$. Through induction, we can find that the top square is equal to ${10\choose0}x_0 + {10\choose1}x_1 + {10\choose2}x_2 + \ldots {10\choose10}x_{10}$.
 (This also makes sense based on a combinatorial argument: the number of ways a number can "travel" to the top position going only up is equal to the number of times it will be counted in the final sum.)
 Examine the equation $\mod 3$. All of the coefficients from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ will be multiples of $3$ (since the numerator will have a $9$).
 Thus, the expression boils down to $x_0 + 10x_1 + 10x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Reduce to find that $x_0 + x_1 + x_9 + x_{10} \equiv 0 \mod 3$. Out of $x_0,\ x_1,\ x_9,\ x_{10}$, either all are equal to $0$, or three of them are equal to $1$.
 This gives ${4\choose0} + {4\choose3} = 1 + 4 = 5$ possible combinations of numbers that work. The seven terms from $x_2 \ldots x_8$ can assume either $0$ or $1$, giving us $2^7$ possibilities. The answer is therefore $5 \cdot 2^7 = \boxed{640}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes k :: nat and triangular_array :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> k \<longrightarrow> triangular_array k i = (triangular_array (k - 1) (i - 1) + triangular_array (k - 1) i) mod 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 11 \<longrightarrow> triangular_array 11 i \<in> {0, 1}"
and h2 : "count (\<lambda> x. triangular_array 1 1 = x mod 3) [0, 1] = 640"
shows  "count (\<lambda> x. triangular_array 1 1 = x mod 3) [0, 1] = 640"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a triangular array with 11 rows. The elements in the k-th row are determined by the following rule: for each $1 \leq i \leq k$, the element at position $i$ in the k-th row is equal to the sum of the elements at positions $i-1$ and $i$ in the $(k-1)$-th row modulo 3. Furthermore, all elements in the 11th row are either 0 or 1. Find the number of times the element at position 1 in the first row is congruent to 0 or 1 modulo 3. The final answer is 640.
